Definition: You have been given a comment from some user from the dataset of civil comment, categorize the comment on the basis of threat of comment. If the comment is threatening output Yes, otherwise output No.

Positive Examples.input: Baloney.  You are going to see real action against Herr Trump and his white supremacist agenda.
Positive Examples.explanation: The comment suggests threat against Trump and his agendas and classified as threatening. Hence, it is a positive example
The comment suggests appreciation without any threats. It is classified as not threatening . Therefore, this is a positive example.

Negative Examples.input: Yet call out all Muslims for the acts of a few will get you pilloried. So why is it okay to smear an entire religion over these few idiots? Or is this because it's okay to bash Christian sects?
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment is genuine argument with no particular threat to Muslims or Christians, but classified as threatening. Therefore, this is a negative example.

Negative Examples.input: It's ridiculous that these guys are being called 'protesters'. Being armed is a threat of violence, which makes them terrorists
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment gives a claim and then tries to justify their claim. No threats have been made but its classified as threatening. Therefore, this is a negative example.

I have owned rental property in various cities (Portland, Chicago, Los Angeles), and even when I am very clear in the ad that the unit is available for a one or two year term lease, well over 50% of the inquiries I receive are always people asking if they can do a shorter lease term.  And this is for everything from small studio accessory dwelling units to 4bd/3ba houses.  There is a significant demand for shorter term leases, even among people whose finances are rock solid, so it's not a living-paycheck-to-paycheck phenomenon.

If a landlord is the one refusing to offer a longer term lease because they want to jack up the rent every other month, I think that is different, but as I said elsewhere in this thread, any good landlord is going to want a longer-term lease and will screen carefully to get a nice, low-hassle tenant, because that is win-win.

Way back, many decades ago, as I was growing up, my Father told me a very simple difference between Democrats and Republicans. He said that the philosophy of the Democrats was that if business paid the workers well and cared about their welfare, business would be very successful. The republicans philosophy was that if business was successful then workers would also profit very well. It seemed to me that both philosophies were correct and it was just a matter of perception. Our political system has ventured a long ways from those basic premises now! It's hard to tell one liar from the other and there seems to be no real platform at all, in either party. The only perception the public has now, is that they are legislators, with immunity to all laws they write and since they are legislators, they can do anything they want to! We've come a long way in 70 years. So far that I can't recognize either party!

During the first decade plus of this century, Portland added hundreds of thousands of people and jobs without seeing any increase in automobile traffic. The exception proves the rule here; more people does not necessarily mean more congestion. It really depends on several factors. Unfortunately, Eugene is failing on all of those factors.

Our roadways are so uninviting to walk and cycle on that we have lost 37% of our cyclists back into cars over the past six years. I wonder if we will ever have any traffic law enforcement or sensible traffic diversions and signal cycles. Heck, I'd settle for not being harassed by the drunks who are living on the bike paths. 

Our mass transit system is a near-complete failure. We have encouraged the placement of nearly all our destination shopping facilities to near-freeway locations and we never but never do anything to inhibit the driving of the suburbanites.

We have tremendous potential, but our reality is no where near it.

This is the version of the Second Amendment as ratified and omits 2 commas present in the original handwritten document. The phrase "shall not be infringed" has been interpreted by the Supreme Court in D.C. v Heller to mean this right exists prior to the Constitution rather than being a right granted by the government. While the anti-gun lobby incorrectly interprets the "well regulated militia" phrase as the sole purpose for the right to keep and bear arms, that interpretation is contrary to over 224 years of law and common practice since the amendment was ratified. The public funded primary should not be reserved for the exclusive use by the organized political parties.  All candidates who meet the minimum qualifications for inclusion on the ballot should be listed on the primary ballot and the two candidates, regardless of party affiliation, who garner the most votes would proceed to the General Election.  That is known as the "top two" primary system which has been adopted in several states over the vociferous  objections of those in power.   In Alaska a bill before this legislature in January 2105 to adopt the "top two " system (HB17)was held to death by the Chair (Bob Lynn) of the first committee of referral (HSA) without a single hearing allowed.    The intent of banning independents from the primary is to deny them the momentum that is afforded to the party candidates who will now be the subject of media attention.  This will probably be that last time they are mentioned in the press until just before the General Election in November.

It's about time. The practice of dumping and reloading at the transfer station in Glenwood has been archaic for years. Yes, trash haulers will drive more, but the increase is marginal at best, and wait times at Short Mountain will be no longer, and more likely much less, than at Glenwood. This will also transfer the cost of trash hauling to the user, rather than the general taxpayer. It will, to a small extent, reduce the amount of time load on city streets, with a somewhat minimal reduction in additional road damage caused by the heavy axle loads of full trash vehicles. Finally, it will permit the County to sell or redevelop that large Glenwood transfer station, which will have both tax and economic development benefits to the county and both cities. No, it won't reduce taxes, but keep in mind the County has been unable to fund many services because of budget issues. The question is how will this better enable them to meet citizens needs.

As one of four rambunctious brothers whose mom was home while dad worked for the phone company, my sibs and I occasionally crossed a line with mom. More Humane Conditions for Elephants
Outdoor space will increase from 1.5 to 6 acres, adding watering holes, shade structures, large trees, and boulders, providing more outside exercise and offering a more natural environment.

Protecting the Health of Polar Bears

More Humane Enclosures for Apes and Monkeys
A renovated exhibit will replace the current cage-like conditions with larger indoor and outdoor areas, adding running water and more natural conditions.

There's a bit of difference between the devices you suggest and a gun in terms of risk mitigation. 
A seatbelt is a risk mitigation device. It does nothing to prevent an accident. It reduces the risk of harm due to the accident. Wearing or not wearing a seatbelt does not alter the underlying risk or make me more prone to accident 

Locking my door does not prevent a robbery. It serves to prevent a specific type of robbery - but does not prevent all robberies. 

Can you point to any other situation where the device used to mitigate the risk is directly tied to or source of the risk? We don't mitigate the risk of an oil spill by spilling oil. We don't mitigate the risk of a car crash by crashing a car. Yet we encourage people to mitigate possible instances of violence, often perpetrated with guns, by carrying that same device as the mitigator?

If fatigue is the primary symptom, its important to rule out Sleep Apnea as a possible cause. I was once given a clinical diagnosis of Lyme and the treatments didn't do anything to my symptoms. A long story short, it turned out that the problem was nothing more than Sleep Apnea. Unfortunately, the Lyme doctor, along with several other medical practitioners including naturopaths, allopaths, cardiologists and an endocrinologist even considered or mentioned it. It stayed under their radar. 

A friend of mine who thought he had Lyme asked his doctor about Sleep Apnea and the doctor said to him "Oh you don't look like you have Sleep Apnea" which is like saying "Oh you don't look like you have Type O Blood." Totally incorrect. Sleep Apnea can be only diagnosed with a Sleep Study and its worth getting if only to rule it out as a causative factor. Turned out my friend has severe Sleep Apnea and using a CPAP machine has given him his life back. 

Same with me. I doubt if I ever had Lyme!
